word.entryDescription: land of a particular kind
word.entryExample: A steppe is usually a dry terrain of grass and very few trees.

word.entryDescription: very bad
word.entryExample: It was a terrible holiday.

word.entryDescription: extremely frightening
word.entryExample: Did you see the avalanche? It was completely terrifying!

word.entryDescription: a set of questions or activities designed to measure somebody's knowledge or ability
word.entryExample: We have a maths test on Tuesday.

word.entryDescription: to send somebody a text message on a mobile device
word.entryExample: I sent you a text this morning.

word.entryDescription: a short written message that is sent or received on mobile phone
word.entryExample: My son has just sent me a text message.

word.entryDescription: of or from Thailand
word.entryExample: Let's go to this new Thai restaurant in town.

word.entryDescription: used to link two things when comparing them
word.entryExample: She's taller than her sister.

word.entryDescription: something you say to show that you are grateful for something they have said or done
word.entryExample: 'I made you a cup of tea.' 'Thank you.'

word.entryDescription: informal word for 'thank you'
word.entryExample: 'Here are the sausages for you.' 'Thanks.'

word.entryDescription: a public holiday in the US and in Canada for people to be thankful for what they have
word.entryExample: They have started to prepare for Thanksgiving.

word.entryDescription: with a roof made of straw, reeds, etc"
word.entryExample: This is the photo of a thatched cottage in the countryside by the river.

word.entryDescription: a white long-sleeved garment worn by Muslim men in the Arabian peninsula (other names: dishdasha, thobe)
word.entryExample: I didn't recognize him at first as he was wearing a thawb.

word.entryDescription: the morning after today
word.entryExample: The next morning the weather was beautiful and we went sailing.

word.entryDescription: one of the two imaginary lines around the world, which is 23½º north of the equator
word.entryExample: The Tropic of Cancer is also referred to as the Northern Tropic.

word.entryDescription: one of the two imaginary lines around the world, which is 23½º south of the equator
word.entryExample: The Tropic of Capricorn runs through South Africa.

word.entryDescription: a place where you can see a play
word.entryExample: We went to the theatre with friends.

word.entryDescription: an amusement park designed around a central theme, such as water or space travel, where people go to enjoy themselves, for example by riding on roller coasters, etc
word.entryExample: There’s no beach or theme park but there’s a shopping centre and a small theatre.

word.entryDescription: used to refer to at least two people or things affected by an action when they also perform the action
word.entryExample: They've injured themselves.

word.entryDescription: next; after that
word.entryExample: The next lesson is English then it's music.

word.entryDescription: a treatment for an illness, injury or condition, particularly one which continues for a long time
word.entryExample: Many different animals are used in therapy.

word.entryDescription: as a result; consequently
word.entryExample: A huge black bear was hungry, therefore it started to look for food in areas where people lived.

word.entryDescription: something that controls temperature
word.entryExample: The integral thermostat guarantees that shower water temperature stays constant even if taps are turned on elsewhere.

word.entryDescription: somebody who steals
word.entryExample: The thief stole my bag.

word.entryDescription: someone who is thin has a narrow body without any fat on it
word.entryExample: You look very thin in this picture.

word.entryDescription: an object that you are not naming
word.entryExample: One more thing, please remember to buy a mat for your bedroom.

word.entryDescription: to have an opinion or belief, or to use your mind
word.entryExample: What do you think about the card we made for you?

word.entryDescription: in the position of number three when we count
word.entryExample: My birthday is on the third of May.

word.entryDescription: the need to drink
word.entryExample: They suffer from hunger and thirst.

word.entryDescription: needing a drink
word.entryExample: You can drink the mineral water when you're thirsty.

word.entryDescription: the number 13
word.entryExample: Thirteen is my lucky number.

word.entryDescription: thinking of nice things to do for other people
word.entryExample: It was very thoughtful of you to buy me a present.

word.entryDescription: something which expresses to somebody that something unpleasant will happen to them, especially if they fail to act in a particular way
word.entryExample: The change in global climates is the main threat to animals.

word.entryDescription: the number 3
word.entryExample: We finish lessons at three.

word.entryDescription: an exciting story often about murder
word.entryExample: I like thrillers, especially those with a crime to solve.

word.entryDescription: exciting and enjoyable
word.entryExample: It's nowhere near as thrilling as the first two series.

word.entryDescription: to be successful, or to develop well
word.entryExample: Thanks to laws protecting them, wolves are now thriving in this area.

word.entryDescription: from one end of something to the other while being surrounded by it
word.entryExample: Go through the car park and turn left at the end.

word.entryDescription: to make something move through the air, using your hand or arm
word.entryExample: In this game you throw a ball to your friend.

word.entryDescription: the sudden loud noise that you might hear during a storm, often after you see lightning
word.entryExample: Britain gets storms too, with gales, thunder and lightning, so sometimes it's best to stay indoors.

word.entryDescription: a storm with thunder and lightning
word.entryExample: There's going to be a thunderstorm tonight.

word.entryDescription: the energy that comes from the sea's waves
word.entryExample: Renewable energy includes things like solar and tidal energy.

word.entryDescription: the flow of water that happens as the sea rises and falls
word.entryExample: Twice a day, at high tide, it is possible to snorkel or dive the reef.

word.entryDescription: to put things in order or in the right place in a house
word.entryExample: She must tidy the house on Saturdays.

word.entryDescription: a long thin cloth worn in the collar of a shirt
word.entryExample: He has to wear a shirt and a tie at work.

word.entryDescription: an Asian animal like a large cat with orange and black stripes
word.entryExample: Are there any tigers in Africa?

word.entryDescription: fitting very closely and often uncomfortably
word.entryExample: I'm not sure about this dress. I'd prefer it to be a little less tight.

word.entryDescription: the thing that is measured in seconds, minutes, hours, days, etc
word.entryExample: What time do you have breakfast?

word.entryDescription: a list of classes showing when they happen
word.entryExample: How about making a homework timetable so you know what you're doing when.

word.entryDescription: = can (a sealed metal food or drinks container)
word.entryExample: Both paper bags and tin cans were invented in the 19th Century.
